newsitem.title: USA: Worker killed at U.S. Steel plant explosion.
newsitem.headline: Worker killed at U.S. Steel plant explosion.

text.p: A steelworker was killed on Sunday by a projectile from an explosion at a U.S. Steel plant, the second fatal accident in the past three days at steel-making plants in Northwest Indiana, authorities said.

The cause of Sunday's explosion at U.S. Steel's Gary Works was not known, but a spokesman for parent company USX Corp. said molten steel likely came in contact with water in a slag pit alongside a blast furnace, triggering the blast.
"Apparently molten iron ... probably encountered some water that created steam, pressure and a significant eruption," USX spokesman Ernie Glenn said.
"(The explosion) launched some sort of projectile which apparently struck the victim in the head, killing him," he said. The name of the worker was not released.
A blast furnance produces molten iron drawn from iron ore and coke, and slag is the super-heated byproduct produced by the process.
The U.S. Steel plant employs about 7,500 people along Lake Michigan about 20 miles southeast of Chicago.
Two workers at Inland Steel Industries Inc.'s plant in East Chicago, Indiana, died of burns sustained when molten steel spilled onto them in an accident on Friday.

Following the accident at Inland Steel on Friday, steelworker C.J. Jones Jr., 61, died at the University of Chicago Hospital's burn unit, and Keith Laczi, 42, died on Saturday at Loyola University Medical Centre in suburban Maywood, Illinois.
